value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: Tens from 50 to 90 are borrowed from Tsakhur (except for Kabakhchol dialect [112]). 10—40 are said to be similar to literary Avar, except for unsignificant phonetic differences, so the underlying native system is vigesimal.
example_comment: The numeral is borrowed from Tsakhur

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: 90' is ač'un-na (without -c'a).
example_comment: The root for 'three' is ɬaɬa, so this is not reduplication.

feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: The situation is unclear. Consider examples: ɬab-ac’a ‘30’ [magomedova2012: 145] // ɬab-ac’a-ja ‘30’ [authierdraft2020: 15]. Here I trust [magomedova2012] more as the second source is a draft.
example_comment: Whether -ja/-da NUM is present in '30', is unclear (sources differ).

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: -ij- component is of an unknown source. It is present in different tens (лъиб-ий-<тI>у ‘30’ with лъиб-<тI>у '3', букь:-ий-<тI>у ‘40’, etc). '10' itself has a root wic'- (вицI-и<тI>у '10').

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: The derivation of tens is mostly vigesimal. '40' is jaxc'ur, '50' is jaxc'ur-ni c'ud (this word «is not synchronically transparent [but cf. Šaumjan 1938]»).

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: /r/ is said to be a petrified class marker but according to [magometov1965: 160], it was not petrified and maintained inflection. /c'/ components denoting 'ten' have undergone phonetic changes in some tens (сум-чIур ‘30’). The word for '40' is jä:ɣčʷur, [magometov1965: 160] notices that it does not inflect in class.

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: According to [magometov1965: 160], the class marker was not petrified and maintained inflection. In this particular village Khiv of Southern Tabasaran dialect, the vigesimal system is present. The only exception is '40', which has its own word instead of 2 x 20. The word is the same as in Standard Tabasaran: jä:ɣčʷur '40'. In adjacent villages, there are some mixed systems (some tens remain vigesimal, some are decimal).

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: In Fite dialect, decimal system is more frequently used. Tens 30–50 and 80 end with -c'ur (xim-c'ur '30') and unit roots seem to have undergone phonetic changes (cf. xibu-d '3'). Numerals 60, 70, and 90 end with -jic' (jerk'y jic' '90'), and unit roots are unchanged (jerk'y-d '9').

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: In Fite dialect, vigesimal system is still preserved but not frequently used. All tens 30—90 except 40 have alternative vigesimal derivations. '40' is always jaɣc'ur but '50' can be derived vigesimally.
example_comment: It is questioned whether -n in q:a-n '20' is a separate morpheme from the root.

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: In Usug village dialect, vigesimal system is used. All tens 30—90 except 40 have alternative vigesimal derivations. '40' is always jaɣc'ur. It is different from Fite vigesimal system in that '50' is derived from '40' jaɣc'ur rather than from non-existent vigesimal '40' *q'ˤu-q:a-d.

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: In Burshag dialect, decimal system is used. Unlike in Fite, all tens 30–90 end with -c'ur (jarš-c'ur '60', cf. Fite jerxi-jic') and unit roots seem to have undergone phonetic changes (cf. jerši-r '6'). Unlike in other dialects, the petrified ending is -r instead of -d (in all numerals).

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: Morpheme -c’alʲ is used for derivation of tens 30—90. Ibragimov thought that «-c’alʲ is erdoded jic'-, having lost the initial syllable and attached -lʲ, which is a petrified class marker». In my opinion, this is likely connected to -cal in Lak & Dargwa languages (however, [ibragimov1990: 3] writes that Tsakhur contacts with Laks and Archis are weak).

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: Kina Rutul tens use either -c'ɨr (30, 60, 70, 80) or -c'ur (jow-c'ur '40', xu-c'ur '50'). '90' is jud͡ʒur (probably originally -c'ur but changed phonetically due to consonant cluster [č'c']?). /r/ is said to be a petrified class marker.

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: 30, 50, 60, 70 are derived vigesimally. 40 is rather weird: q:ʷa-q:ʷaʕa-r (cf. q'ʷa-r '2', qaˤ-r '20'), with q:ʷa-q:ʷaʕa-r-na jic'-ir as '50'. '80' can be derived as juq'-qa-d but Azeri-borrowed saksan is also used. It it is said that 60—90 are being replaced with Azeri cardinals. No native numeral for '90' is given, only Azeri duqsan.

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: According to chunks of information from dictionaries [mobili2010] and [gukasyan1974], in Nizh Udi Azeri numerals are used for tens. In tens with units, Azeri tens are used along with native units (q’irx-bip’ '44' [mobili2010: 239]).

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: According to chunks of information from dictionaries [mobili2010] and [gukasyan1974], in Vartashen Udi vigesimal system is preserved. [mobili2010: 328] claims this is true for Oghuz dialect, [gukasyan1974] attributes this to Vartashen dialect. It is unclear to me whether the same idiom is meant in these cases.

value1_name: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
feature: Special endings for crowns from 30 to 90
comment: An old article by Chernij (1869/1905) has indications of a vigesimal system which is probably an influence of [East] Caucasian languages. However, no examples are given. The current system is decimal, roots are Iranian.
